key_facts: Reinforcement learning (RL) was first applied to robotics in the 1980s, with early successes including robotic arm control and motion planning.
In the 1990s, RL-based control systems were developed for autonomous vehicles, such as the Stanford Cart, which navigated through a maze using RL.
Today, RL is used in various robotics applications, including grasping and manipulation, human-robot collaboration, and mobile manipulation.

main_concepts.name: Reinforcement Learning (RL)
main_concepts.definition: A machine learning approach where an agent learns to take actions in an environment to maximize a reward signal.

main_concepts.name: Embodied AI
main_concepts.definition: The integration of artificial intelligence with the physical world, enabling robots to learn from and adapt to their surroundings.

relationships: RL is a key component of embodied AI, as it enables robots to learn from their experiences and adjust their behavior accordingly.
The development of RL-based control systems has led to significant advancements in robotics, including improved task performance, adaptability, and robustness.
potential_sections: Early Years: A historical overview of the evolution of RL in robotics, highlighting key milestones and breakthroughs.
Current State: An analysis of modern RL-based robotic systems, discussing their applications, challenges, and future directions.
Emerging Trends: Exploring emerging areas of research, such as multimodal learning, transfer learning, and explainability, which are shaping the future of RL in robotics.
